result.markdown:
--- title: "POST 2" subtitle: "Network Exploration" author: "Sue-Ellen Duffy" date: "2024-04-26" categories: [code, analysis] --- ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(readr) library(igraph) library(sna) library(ggplot2) library(kableExtra) library(patchwork) ``` ::: This post will explore the Synthetic Mass network data in more detail. # Read in Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pat_attr <- read_csv("post1drug_data/pat_attr.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) pro_attr <- read_csv("post1drug_data/pro_attr.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) encounters_cleaning <- read_csv("post1drug_data//encounters_cleaning.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) encounters_cleaned <- read_csv("post1drug_data//encounters_cleaned.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) encounter_attributes <- read_csv("post1drug_data/encounter_attributes.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) encounters_el <- read_csv("post1drug_data/encounters_el.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) encounters_st_3 <- read_csv("post1drug_data/encounters.st.3.csv", col_types = cols(...1 = col_skip())) attribute_list <- read.csv("post1drug_data/attribute_list.csv") ``` ::: # Prep Data for Analysis ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #combine pro and pat attr pat_attr$type <- "PATIENT" pro_attr$type <- "PROVIDER" both_attr <- bind_rows(pat_attr, pro_attr) head(both_attr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 Ã— 8 NAME GENDER RACE MARITAL CITY INCOME AGE type 1 Annice210 Gleason633 Female white Married brookline 1565 37 PATIENT 2 Julianne852 Barrows492 Female white Widowed hamilton 39537 65 PATIENT 3 Alesha810 Heaney114 Female white Divorced framingham 114339 46 PATIENT 4 Sandee884 Rice937 Female white taunton 96256 26 PATIENT 5 Mia349 Runte676 Female white Divorced chelmsford 71238 44 PATIENT 6 Damian46 Dach178 Male white swansea 74155 26 PATIENT ``` ::: ::: # Create bipartite network with attributes ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} encounters.st.3 <- network(encounters_el, directed = FALSE, bipartite = TRUE, matrix.type = "edgelist", vertex.attr = attribute_list) encounters.st.3 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Network attributes: vertices = 308 directed = FALSE hyper = FALSE loops = FALSE multiple = FALSE bipartite = 86 total edges= 341 missing edges= 0 non-missing edges= 341 Vertex attribute names: AGE CITY GENDER INCOME MARITAL NAME RACE type vertex.names X Edge attribute names: COUNT ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} head(network.vertex.names( encounters.st.3)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "Adam631 Hoppe518" "Alesha810 Heaney114" [3] "Alissa315 Altenwerth646" "Analisa263 Kohler843" [5] "Annice210 Gleason633" "Anthony633 Kutch271" ``` ::: ::: # Graphs ## Graphs with sna ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load the sna library to get the gplot() function library( sna ) # set the seed to reproduce the plot layout set.seed( 507 ) # execute the plot gplot( encounters.st.3, gmode = "twomode", # indicate it is two modes usearrows = FALSE, # turn off the arrowheads vertex.cex=2, # size the nodes label.cex=1.2, # size the labels main="Bipartite Graph of Encounters using SNA" # add a title ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} incidence_graph <- graph_from_biadjacency_matrix(encounters.st.3) ``` ::: detach("package:sna") ## Graphs with igraph ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} vertex_colors <- ifelse(attribute_list$GENDER == "Female", "pink", "turquoise") V(incidence_graph)$shape <- ifelse(V(incidence_graph)$type, "square", "circle") # Define edge colors based on COUNT attribute edge_colors <- ifelse(encounters_el$COUNT < 5, "lightblue", ifelse(encounters_el$COUNT <= 20, "blue", ifelse(encounters_el$COUNT <= 100, "darkblue", "red"))) # Check if the length of edge_colors matches the number of edges if (length(edge_colors) == ecount(incidence_graph)) { # Set edge attributes based on counts E(incidence_graph)$color <- edge_colors } else { print("Length of edge_colors does not match the number of edges in the graph.") } E(incidence_graph)$color <- edge_colors # set the seed to reproduce the plot layout set.seed( 235 ) plot(incidence_graph, layout = layout.fruchterman.reingold, vertex.label.dist = 2, vertex.size = 3, vertex.color = vertex_colors, edge.label = NA, vertex.label = NA, vertex.label.cex = 0.2, main = "Patient Provider Incidence Graph") # Define legend for vertex colors legend("bottomright", legend = c("Female", "Male"), # You can customize these labels fill = c("pink", "turquoise"), # Fill colors corresponding to vertex colors title = "Nodes: Gender") # Legend title # Define legend for vertex shapes legend("topright", legend = c("Patient", "Provider"), # You can customize these labels pch = c(1, 0), # Point shapes corresponding to vertex shapes title = "Nodes: Who") # Legend title # Define legend for edge colors legend("topleft", legend = c("1-4", "5-19", "20-99", "100+"), # You can customize these labels col = c("lightblue", "blue", "darkblue", "red"), # Line colors corresponding to edge colors lwd = 2, # Line width title = "Edges: # of Visits") # Legend title ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #Calculating centrality types <- V(incidence_graph)$type types <- ifelse(types, "PROVIDER", "PATIENT") deg<- round(igraph::degree(incidence_graph),2) bet <- round(igraph::betweenness(incidence_graph), 0) clos <- round(igraph::closeness(incidence_graph),4) eig <- round(eigen_centrality(incidence_graph)$vector,2) const <- round(constraint(incidence_graph),2) cent_df <- data.frame(types, deg, bet, clos, eig, const) head(cent_df[order(cent_df$deg, decreasing = TRUE),], 10)%>% kbl(caption = "Centrality Measures for Encounter Network") %>% kable_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Centrality Measures for Encounter Network
types deg bet clos eig const
Ted955 Reilly981 PROVIDER 17 18289 0.0014 1.00 0.06
Jewel43 Kassulke119 PROVIDER 9 5293 0.0010 0.12 0.11
Ramon749 Kozey370 PATIENT 8 5920 0.0012 0.31 0.12
Sabine292 Feil794 PATIENT 7 8039 0.0012 0.28 0.14
Tomika243 Walker122 PATIENT 7 928 0.0007 0.00 0.14
Gordon377 Marquardt819 PATIENT 6 2112 0.0011 0.28 0.17
Lan153 Schmidt332 PATIENT 6 942 0.0009 0.04 0.17
Stanley702 Cremin516 PATIENT 6 823 0.0007 0.00 0.17
Cortez851 Price929 PROVIDER 6 4823 0.0008 0.00 0.17
Anderson154 Lemke654 PROVIDER 6 2267 0.0010 0.23 0.17
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(cent_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` types deg bet clos Length:308 Min. : 1.000 Min. : 0.0 Min. :0.00050 Class :character 1st Qu.: 1.000 1st Qu.: 0.0 1st Qu.:0.00070 Mode :character Median : 1.000 Median : 0.0 Median :0.00090 Mean : 2.214 Mean : 375.7 Mean :0.03741 3rd Qu.: 3.000 3rd Qu.: 222.2 3rd Qu.:0.05560 Max. :17.000 Max. :18289.0 Max. :0.33330 eig const Min. :0.00000 Min. :0.0600 1st Qu.:0.00000 1st Qu.:0.3300 Median :0.00500 Median :1.0000 Mean :0.03883 Mean :0.6736 3rd Qu.:0.05000 3rd Qu.:1.0000 Max. :1.00000 Max. :1.0000 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Distribution visualization hist(cent_df$deg, main = "Degree Centrality Distribution", xlab = "Degree") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Correlation analysis correlation_matrix <- cor(cent_df[, c("deg", "bet", "clos", "eig", "const")]) correlation_matrix <- round(correlation_matrix, 2) correlation_matrix %>% kbl(caption = "Correlation Matrix of Centrality Measures for Encounter Network") %>% kable_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Correlation Matrix of Centrality Measures for Encounter Network
deg bet clos eig const
deg 1.00 0.73 -0.10 0.65 -0.83
bet 0.73 1.00 -0.14 0.71 -0.37
clos -0.10 -0.14 1.00 -0.23 0.06
eig 0.65 0.71 -0.23 1.00 -0.39
const -0.83 -0.37 0.06 -0.39 1.00
````` ::: ::: Positive Correlation: The correlation of 0.73 between degree and betweenness centrality (deg and bet) suggests that nodes with higher degree tend to also have higher betweenness centrality. Negative Correlation: The correlation of -0.83 between degree and constraint (deg and const) suggests that nodes with higher degree tend to have lower constraint. Weak Correlation: The correlation between closeness centrality and other measures (bet, eig, const) is relatively weak, with coefficients close to 0, indicating weak or no linear relationship. Higher eigenvector centrality and betweenness centrality are positively correlated. These nodes have strong influence and act as important intermediaries in the network. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} #provider only pro_cent_df <- cent_df %>% filter(types =="TRUE") head(pro_cent_df[order(pro_cent_df$deg, decreasing = TRUE),], 10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] types deg bet clos eig const <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(pro_cent_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` types deg bet clos eig Length:0 Min. : NA Min. : NA Min. : NA Min. : NA Class :character 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA Mode :character Median : NA Median : NA Median : NA Median : NA Mean :NaN Mean :NaN Mean :NaN Mean :NaN 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA Max. : NA Max. : NA Max. : NA Max. : NA const Min. : NA 1st Qu.: NA Median : NA Mean :NaN 3rd Qu.: NA Max. : NA ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} #patient only pat_cent_df <- cent_df %>% filter(types =="FALSE") head(pat_cent_df[order(pat_cent_df$deg, decreasing = TRUE),], 10) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] types deg bet clos eig const <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} summary(pat_cent_df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` types deg bet clos eig Length:0 Min. : NA Min. : NA Min. : NA Min. : NA Class :character 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA 1st Qu.: NA Mode :character Median : NA Median : NA Median : NA Median : NA Mean :NaN Mean :NaN Mean :NaN Mean :NaN 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA 3rd Qu.: NA Max. : NA Max. : NA Max. : NA Max. : NA const Min. : NA 1st Qu.: NA Median : NA Mean :NaN 3rd Qu.: NA Max. : NA ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} V(incidence_graph)$size <- igraph::degree(incidence_graph) # set the seed to reproduce the plot layout set.seed( 235 ) plot(incidence_graph, layout = layout.fruchterman.reingold, vertex.color = vertex_colors, edge.color = "gray", edge.label = NA, vertex.label = NA, main = "Patient Provider Incidence Graph with Degree Information") # Define legend for vertex colors legend("bottomright", legend = c("Female", "Male"), # You can customize these labels fill = c("pink", "turquoise"), # Fill colors corresponding to vertex colors title = "Nodes: Gender") # Legend title # Define legend for vertex shapes legend("topright", legend = c("Patient", "Provider"), # You can customize these labels pch = c(1, 0), # Point shapes corresponding to vertex shapes title = "Nodes: Who") # Legend title # Define legend for edge colors legend("topleft", legend = "Vertex Size", pch = 1, pt.cex = seq(0.5, 3, length.out = 5), title = "Degree") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Here we can see there is one Provider that sees the most patients, with degree centrality = 28. The next largest degree centrality are in the 5 to 7 range and the majority of those nodes are patients. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} V(incidence_graph)$size <- igraph::closeness(incidence_graph) # set the seed to reproduce the plot layout set.seed( 235 ) plot(incidence_graph, layout = layout.fruchterman.reingold, vertex.color = vertex_colors, edge.color = "gray", edge.label = NA, vertex.label = NA, main = "Patient Provider Incidence Graph with Closeness Information") # Define legend for vertex colors legend("bottomright", legend = c("Female", "Male"), # You can customize these labels fill = c("magenta", "blue"), # Fill colors corresponding to vertex colors title = "Nodes: Gender") # Legend title # Define legend for vertex shapes legend("topright", legend = c("Patient", "Provider"), # You can customize these labels pch = c(1, 0), # Point shapes corresponding to vertex shapes title = "Nodes: Who") # Legend title # Define legend for edge colors legend("topleft", legend = "Vertex Size", pch = 1, pt.cex = seq(0.5, 3, length.out = 5), title = "Closeness") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Here we see two of the dyads on the outer right side of this incidence graph have the largest closeness score. This is because their network is complete (they are both connected to one another). # Triad Dyad Census ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} triads_incidence<-igraph::triad_census(incidence_graph) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in igraph::triad_census(incidence_graph): At vendor/cigraph/src/misc/motifs.c:1140 : Triad census called on an undirected graph. All connections will be treated as mutual. ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} triads_incidence ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 4718886 0 102594 0 0 0 0 0 0 [10] 0 876 0 0 0 0 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} igraph::dyad_census(incidence_graph) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: `dyad_census()` requires a directed graph. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $mut [1] 341 $asym [1] 0 $null [1] 46937 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} transitivity(incidence_graph) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} transitivity(incidence_graph, type = "global") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 0 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} mean_distance(incidence_graph) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 6.160216 ``` ::: ::: # Component Structure and Membership First, let's look at the network component structure. This gives a list with: membership by node, size of each component, and the total number of components. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} names(igraph::components(incidence_graph)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "membership" "csize" "no" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} igraph::components(incidence_graph)$no # number of components ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 17 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} igraph::components(incidence_graph)$csize #Size of each component ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 211 7 6 7 4 6 9 7 4 4 5 8 9 8 4 4 5 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} degree.wt=strength(incidence_graph) ``` ::: # Graph Cluster ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glou <- graph_from_data_frame(encounters_el[, 1:2], directed = FALSE) lou <- cluster_louvain(glou) set.seed(1) plot(lou, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size=2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1) plot(lou, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size=5, mark.groups = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1) plot(lou, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size = 5, mark.border = NA) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-3.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glou <- graph_from_data_frame(encounters_el[, 1:2], directed = FALSE) walktrap <- cluster_leading_eigen(glou) set.seed(1) plot(walktrap, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size=2) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1) plot(walktrap, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size=5, mark.groups = NULL) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(1) plot(walktrap, glou, vertex.label = NA, vertex.size = 5, mark.border = NA) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](post_2_drug_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-3.png){width=672} ::: ::: # Graph Providers and Patients Separately ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} projected_graph <- bipartite_projection(incidence_graph) #providers head(projected_graph$proj2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 6 x 222 sparse Matrix of class "dgCMatrix" ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` [[ suppressing 222 column names 'Elijah719 White193', 'Fidel864 Swift555', 'Virgen207 Hyatt152' ... ]] ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Elijah719 White193 . 1 1 1 . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .
